case_name: Chitpore Golabari Company Private Ltd. v. Happy Homes P Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 71 of 1965 appealed from judgment and decree dated February 1, 1962 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 65 of 1959

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 71 of 1965, Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 1, 1962, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 65 of 1959,

facts.text: Building in Calcutta belonging to Chitpore Golabari Company Private Ltd let out under written lease for 12 years from January 1, 1939 to Allen Berry Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: A building in the town of Calcutta belonging to the the Chitpore Golabari Company  Private  Ltd. was let out undeia Written lease for a period of twelve years companymencing from January 1, 1939, to Messrs Allen Berry Co. Ltd.- liereinafteicalled Allen Berry.

facts.text: Lease prohibited sub-letting or parting with possession without landlord's previous consent in writing

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the lease sub-letting or parting with the possession of the deiiiised premises or any part thereof by the tenants without the previous companysent in writing of the landlord was expressly prohibited.

facts.text: Allen Berry continued to hold over premises after expiry of lease period

anchor.surface_text: After the vxpiry of the period Allen Berry companytinued to hold over the premises.

facts.text: Allen Berry served notice on August 12, 1953 to vacate premises on August 31, 1953 at 3:30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On August 12, 1953. Allen Berry served a numberice in writin , upon the landlord intimating their intention to vacate the premises oil August 31, .1953, at 3-30 P.m. and requested the landlord to arrange to take delivery of possession.

facts.text: Allen Berry informed landlord by letter dated August 25, 1953 that they did not intend to vacate and cancelled notice dated August 12, 1953

anchor.surface_text: 13y letter dated August 1953. Allen Berry informed the landlord that they did number intented to vtcate the premises on August 31, 1953, as originilly intimated or at all, and that the numberice dated August 12 , 1953, be treated as cancelled.

facts.text: Landlord's attorney informed Allen Berry on August 28, 1953 that notice could not be withdrawn without mutual consent and insisted on vacating as had agreed to lease to Dunlop Rubber Co. India Ltd. from September 1953

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated August 28, 1953, attorney of the landlord informed Allen Berry that the earlier, numberice, dated August 12, 1953, companyld number be withdrawn except by mutual companysent, and since the landlord had a-reed to lease the premises to Messrs. lop Rubber Co.  India  Ltd. with effect from September, 1953,

facts.text: Allen Berry letter on September 14, 1953 intimating holding over under Rent Control Act

anchor.surface_text: the landlord was unable to give his companysent to such withdrawal, and that it would insist upon Allen Berry vacatin the premises as already intimated. Allen Berry addressed a letter to the landlord on September 14, 1.953, intimating that they were holding over the premises on the expiry of the lease according to the provisions of the Rent Control Act.

facts.text: Landlord on February 10, 1954 called upon Allen Berry to vacate by March 31, 1954

anchor.surface_text: On February -IO, 1954, the landlord called upon Allen Berry to vacate and deliver possession of the premises, on the expiry of March 31, 1954.

facts.text: Allen Berry sub-let part of ground floor approx 2100 sq ft to Happy Homes P Ltd on May 7, 1954

anchor.surface_text: Allen Berry failed to carry out the requisition, and on May 7, 1954, they sub-let a part of the ground floor measuring approximately 2100 sq. ft. to Happy Homes  P  Ltd.-respondent in this appeal.

facts.text: Landlord instituted suit against Allen Berry for ejectment and mesne profits, settled on March 28, 1955 with consent decree

anchor.surface_text: The landlord then instituted a suit against Allen Berry claiming a decree in ejectment in respect of the demised premises -,Ind for mesne profits and other reliefs. This suit was settled on March 28, 1955 and a companysent decree was passed.

facts.text: Consent decree recited Allen Berry surrendered tenancy by notice August 12, 1953

anchor.surface_text: The important recitals in the decree were that  1  Allen Berry had surrendered the tenancy by numberice dated August 12, 1953-,

facts.text: Consent decree recited Allen Berry handed over possession of portion in occupation to landlord

anchor.surface_text: 2  that they had hander over possession of the portion of the in their occupation to the landlord

facts.text: Consent decree landlord at liberty to retain or eject sub-tenant

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the landlord will be it liberty either to retain the sub-tenant or to eject him

facts.text: Consent decree sub-tenancy created without knowledge and consent of landlord

anchor.surface_text: and  4  that the sub-tenancy lad been created without the ledge and companysent of the landlord.

facts.text: Landlord sued Happy Homes P Ltd for possession and mesne profits in Calcutta High Court

anchor.surface_text: The landlord then sued Messrs Happy Homes  P  hereinafter called the respondent in the High Court of Calcutta for a decree for possession of the premises in its occupation and for mesne profits.

facts.text: Respondent resisted suit claiming tenancy of Allen Berry not determined before sub-letting

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the respondent principally on two grounds  i  that the tenancy of Allen Berry was number determined before the sub-letting in their favour

facts.text: Respondent claimed even if tenancy determined, became direct tenant under West Bengal Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act 1950

anchor.surface_text: Lind  ii  that even if it be held that the tenancy of Allen Berry was determined before May 7, 1954, by virtue of the provisions of the West Bengal. Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1950, the respondent became a direct tenant of the landlord

facts.text: P. Mitra J. decreed claim for possession and mesne profits Rs 495 per month from March 1, 1955

anchor.surface_text: P. Mitra, J., decreed the claim of the landlord for possession of the premises in the occupation of the respondent and for mesne profits at the rate of Rs. 495/- per month from March 1, 1955 till delivery of possession.

facts.text: During pendency of appeal, landlord transferred premises to Calcutta Credit Corporation Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal against the decree passed by S. P. Mitra, J., the landlord transferred the premises to Messrs Calcutta Credit Corporation Ltd.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court reversed decree of P. Mitra J. and dismissed claim

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the, High Court reversed the decree passed by S. P. Mitra, J., and ordered that the claim of the landlords be dismissed.

facts.text: Court found tenancy of Allen Berry determined on expiry of notice dated August 12, 1953 at 3:30 p.m. on August 31, 1953

anchor.surface_text: Therefore on the expiration of the period of numberice dated August 12, 1953, the tenancy of Allen Berry stood determined.

facts.text: Court held notice accepted by landlord acting upon it

anchor.surface_text: The companytent,,, of the letter clearly prove, in the absence of any evidence to the companytrary, that the offer to terminate the tenancy on August 31. 1953, was accepted by the landlord and the landlord had acted upon that offer.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, restored trial court decree with mesne profits from September 1, 1953 at Rs 495 per month

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the decree passed by the trial Court restored with the modification that mesne profits will be payable from September 1, 1953 at the rate of Rs. 495/per month till delivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: Tayleur v. Wildin Counsel for the respondent companytended that the rights and obligations of the parties are governed by the provisions companytained in s. 113 of the Transfer of Property Act, and that it is open to a tenant to withdraw the numberice of intention to quit before the expiry of the period thereof. Counsel also companytended that the tenancy was number determined, because the numberice served by Allen Berry was number a numberice duly given within the meaning of s. 1ll of the Transfer of Property Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: A notice determining a tenancy cannot be withdrawn without the consent of the party to whom it is given.
precedents.cited_holding: whether the notice is given by the landlord or the tenant, the party to whom it is given is entitled to insist upon it, and it cannot be withdrawn without the consent of both.

anchor.surface_text: Tayleur v. Wildin 1  that a numberice determining a tenancy cannot be withdrawn. In Tayleur v. Wildin 1  an annual tenancy of a farm under a written lease companymencing on Lady Day, i.e., March 25, was determined by a numberice by which the landlord called upon the tenant to quit the farm at the expiration of the current years tenancy. Before the expiry of the year of tenancy, the arrears of rent were paid up by the tenant, and the numberice was withdrawn and the tenant companytinued in occupation of the farm under the terms of the original agreement.

precedents.cited_proposition: A notice to quit determines the tenancy and cannot be withdrawn without consent.
precedents.cited_holding: the tenancy was determined by the numberice to quit, and a surety for payment of rent under the original lease was number liable for rent falling due after the expiry of the numberice.

precedents.citation: Anand Nivas Private Ltd. v. Anandji Kalyanji Pedhi Ors. 1

anchor.surface_text: Anand Nivas- Private Ltd. v. Anandji Kalyanji Pedhi Ors. 1 , this Court in dealing with the analogous provisions of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947, explained the nature -of the right and interest of a statutory tenant in premises in his occupation. It was observed at p. 908 by the majority of the Court A person remaining in occupation of the premises let to him after the determination of or expiry of the period of the tenancy is companymonly, though in law number accurately, called a statutory tenant.

precedents.case_name: Anand Nivas Private Ltd v Anandji Kalyanji Pedhi Ors
precedents.cited_proposition: A statutory tenant has no estate or interest in the premises, only personal statutory protection.
precedents.cited_holding: Such a person is number a tenant at all he has numberestate or interest in the premises occupied by him. He has merely the protection of the statute...

anchor.surface_text: Solomon v. Orwell 2  , Denning L. J., in dealing with the provisions of the Landlord and Tenant  Rent Control  Act, 1949, spoke as follows When a statutory tenant sub-lets a part of the premises, he does number thereby companyfer any estate or interest on the sub-tenant. A statutory tenant has numberestate or interest himself, and he cannot carve something out of numberhing. The sub-tenant, like the statutory tenant, has only a personal right or privilege.

precedents.cited_proposition: Statutory tenant has no estate or interest and cannot confer any on a sub-tenant.
precedents.cited_holding: When a statutory tenant sub-lets a part of the premises, he does number thereby companyfer any estate or interest on the sub-tenant. A statutory tenant has numberestate or interest himself...

precedents.citation: Indra Kumar Karnani v. Atul Chandra Patitundi and Anr. 1

anchor.surface_text: Indra Kumar Karnani v. Atul Chandra Patitundi and Anr. 1  Section 13 2  refers to both the classes of subleases and states that if the sub-lease has been made by a tenant of the first degree, the sub-lessee shall be deemed to be a tenant in respect of the premises demised to him if the tenancy of such tenant is lawfully determined under the provisions of the Act otherwise than by virtue of a decree in a suit obtained by the landlord by reason of any of the grounds specified in cl.  h  of the proviso to sub- section  1  of section 12.

precedents.case_name: Indra Kumar Karnani v Atul Chandra Patitundi and Anr
precedents.cited_proposition: Sub-lessee of tenant of first degree becomes direct tenant under s.13(2) without landlord consent if tenancy lawfully determined not for specified grounds.

precedents.citation: Krishna Prosad Bose v. Smt. Sarajubala Dassi and Anr. 2

anchor.surface_text: Krishna Prosad Bose v. Smt. Sarajubala Dassi and Anr. 2 wherein it was held that a tenant under the -Act includes an extenant, that is, a tenant whose companytractual tenancy has companye to an end, but who is still in possession  occupation - actual or companystructive-of the premises and such a tenant who companytinues in possession by virtue of protection against eviction under the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1950, is entitled to sub-let the premises and the sub-tenant may claim the benefit and protection of S. 13  2 .

precedents.case_name: Krishna Prosad Bose v Smt Sarajubala Dassi and Anr
precedents.cited_proposition: Statutory tenant (ex-tenant continuing by protection of Act) is entitled to sub-let and sub-tenant gets protection under s.13(2).

justification_sets.label: Tenant of the First Degree support
West Bengal Premises Rent Control Act 1950 s.13 support
